According to news originating from Hohhot, People’ s Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,“ Whether routine urinary analysis has a net benefit for urinary tract infection...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Health &
Medicine Daily \-- Investigators discuss new findings in Health and Medicine -
Translational Medicine. According to news originating from Hohhot, People's
Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Whether routine
urinary analysis has a net benefit for urinary tract infection (UTI) screening
is unclear. Using the laboratory information system (LIS), we retrospectively
extracted the data of urine culture and routine analysis between January 2017
and April 2017."

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Inner Mongolia
Medical University, "Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve, logistic
regression model, net reclassification improvement (NRI) and integrated
discrimination improvement (IDI) were used to estimate the screening
performance of routine urinary analysis. Decision curve analysis (DCA) was
used to estimate the net benefit of routine urinary analysis. A total of 927
specimens with 156 UTIs were included in the present study. The area under ROC
curves (AUCs) of white blood cells (WBCs) and bacteria were 0.729 and 0.836,
respectively. The logistic regression model incorporating WBCs, bacteria and
nitrite together had an AUC of 0.851, which is significantly higher than that
of WBCs. NRI and IDI analyses also indicated that WBCs, bacteria and nitrite,
when used together, had better a screening performance than each single test
alone. DCA revealed that 0.08 net benefit can be obtained for bacteria and the
model, while the net benefit of WBCs is limited. WBCs, bacteria and nitrite,
when used together, can significantly improve the efficiency for UTI
screening."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Bacteria and the model
incorporating WBCs, bacteria and nitrite have a net benefit in UTI screening,
while the net benefit of WBCs, when used alone, is limited."

For more information on this research see: Net benefit of routine urine
parameters for urinary tract infection screening: a decision curve analysis.
_Annals of Translational Medicine_ , 2020;8(9):601-601. _Annals of
Translational Medicine_ can be contacted at: Ame Publ Co, Flat-Rm C 16F, Kings
Wing Plaza 1, No 3 Kwan St, Shatin, Hong Kong 00000, Peoples R China.

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained
from Z.D. Hu, Inner Mongolia Medical University, Dept. of Laboratory Medicine,
Affiliated Hospital, Hohhot 010050, People's Republic of China. Additional
authors for this research include Y.Q. Han, L. Zhang, J.R. Wang and S.C. Xu.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.21037/atm.2019.09.52>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Findings in the Area of Translational Medicine Reported from Inner Mongolia Medical University (Net benefit of routine urine parameters for urinary tract infection screening: a decision curve analysis): Health and Medicine - Translational Medicine
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Health & Medicine Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in Health and Medicine - Translational Medicine. According to news originating from Hohhot, People’s Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “Whether routine urinary analysis has a net benefit for urinary tract infection (UTI) screening is unclear. Using the laboratory information system (LIS), we retrospectively extracted the data of urine culture and routine analysis between January 2017 and April 2017.”

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Inner Mongolia Medical University, “Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve, logistic regression model, net reclassification improvement (NRI) and integrated discrimination improvement (IDI) were used to estimate the screening performance of routine urinary analysis. Decision curve analysis (DCA) was used to estimate the net benefit of routine urinary analysis. A total of 927 specimens with 156 UTIs were included in the present study. The area under ROC curves (AUCs) of white blood cells (WBCs) and bacteria were 0.729 and 0.836, respectively. The logistic regression model incorporating WBCs, bacteria and nitrite together had an AUC of 0.851, which is significantly higher than that of WBCs. NRI and IDI analyses also indicated that WBCs, bacteria and nitrite, when used together, had better a screening performance than each single test alone. DCA revealed that 0.08 net benefit can be obtained for bacteria and the model, while the net benefit of WBCs is limited. WBCs, bacteria and nitrite, when used together, can significantly improve the efficiency for UTI screening.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Bacteria and the model incorporating WBCs, bacteria and nitrite have a net benefit in UTI screening, while the net benefit of WBCs, when used alone, is limited.”

For more information on this research see: Net benefit of routine urine parameters for urinary tract infection screening: a decision curve analysis. Annals of Translational Medicine, 2020;8(9):601-601. Annals of Translational Medicine can be contacted at: Ame Publ Co, Flat-Rm C 16F, Kings Wing Plaza 1, No 3 Kwan St, Shatin, Hong Kong 00000, Peoples R China.

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Z.D. Hu, Inner Mongolia Medical University, Dept. of Laboratory Medicine, Affiliated Hospital, Hohhot 010050, People’s Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Y.Q. Han, L. Zhang, J.R. Wang and S.C. Xu.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.21037/atm.2019.09.52. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
